questions.question:
Question 1: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic because of walking difficulties. His mother says he 
has always walked on his toes and walks by tilting side-to-side. He also has progressive 
muscle weakness. There is no history of trauma, fever, or rash. On examination, calf 
hypertrophy with atrophied thigh muscles is noted as shown below. There is no tenderness on 
palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The finding of enlarged calf muscles and atrophied thigh muscles with a history of muscle 
weakness and waddling gait are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is 
an X-linked recessive disorder. In DMD, pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles which occurs due 
to muscle enlargement by the infiltration of fat. It is paradoxically weak, unlike the muscle that 
enlarges due to hypertrophy. Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles is the characteristic feature of 
DMD, whereas the other 3 conditions mentioned in the options do not have this feature. Clinical features: • Progressive weakness with developmental delay • Pseudohypertrophy of calves • Wasting of thigh muscles • Characteristic Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle. • Gower’s sign • Dilated cardiomyopathy Diagnosis: • Elevated serum creatine kinase levels • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for dystrophin gene 697 
Sold by @itachibot • If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin 
immunocytochemistry is done. Treatment includes supportive management for cardiac decompensation, nutritional 
management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids. Death usually occurs by 18 to 20 years of age 
due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration. Note- The FDA has approved Vamorolone, a novel corticosteroid for the treatment of DMD. The 
drug offers enhanced anti-inflammatory properties and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonism as 
well. It is potentially a safer and more effective alternative to glucocorticoids. Other options: Option B: Myotonic dystrophy presents with distal muscle weakness, proximal muscle 
involvement is very late. Option C: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy. 
Death occurs early. Option D: Emery–Dreifuss muscular dystrophy presents with predominant involvement of 
scapular and humeral muscles. The given question describes the involvement of lower limb 
muscles. Hence, Emery–Dreifuss dystrophy, in this case, is less likely.

questions.question:
Question 2: The image below shows the model of a skeletal muscle fiber. Which of the following 
structures is affected in Duchenne muscular dystrophy? 691 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The structure marked as B in the image represents dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), 
which is absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) due to a mutation in the dystrophin 
gene. This gene is located on the short arm of chromosome X near the p21 locus (Xp21). Lack of 
dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellular 
components. 698 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: Abhi, a young boy is being evaluated in the ward for proximal muscle weakness. Waddling 
gait and Gowers sign are observed in this child. Genetic analysis confirms the diagnosis as 
Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Which of the following is false regarding this patient's 
condition?

options.a: It is less severe than Becker's dystrophy
options.b: Tendon reflexes are lost after age 6
options.c: Gene affected is the largest gene in humans

questions.explanation:
Duchenne muscular dystrophy is more severe than Becker’s dystrophy. In DMD, tendon reflexes 
are lost after age 6. Becker’s dystrophy is similar to Duchenne muscular dystrophy with a genetic defect at the same 
locus (Xp21) but clinically less severe. Gene affected in both is dystrophin, which is the largest 
gene in humans. Important differences between Duchenne and Becker’s muscular dystrophy: Duchenne's dystrophy

questions.question:
Question 4: You observe a six-year-old child in the ward and notice the following. Which of the following 
are true regarding this sign? 692 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows the Gowers sign. Patients use their hands to “climb up” their legs when asked to 
rise from a prone position to compensate for proximal lower-extremity weakness. An early Gowers 
sign is often evident by age of 3 years and is fully expressed by age of 5 or 6 years. This maneuver can be seen in patients with: • Duchenne muscular dystrophy • Becker's muscular dystrophy • Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy • Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy • Polymyositis • Dermatomyositis 699 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A concerned mother brought her son to the clinic because of difficulty writing in school. She 
also says that his eyes remain partially open when he sleeps. There is no history of trauma or 
surgery. On examination, he has asymmetric wrist and finger weakness. The mouth appears 
puckered and rounded, deltoid muscles are flattened and the following finding is observed. 
What is the likely diagnosis? 693 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows winging of the scapula, which when combined with this patient's features are 
suggestive of facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy. Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant condition that generally presents with 
asymmetric weakness in facial and shoulder girdle muscles. Occasionally, finger and wrist 
weakness is the first symptom. The mouth is rounded and appears puckered because of the protruding lips. Upper facial 
weakness will manifest as an inability to close the eyes completely in sleep. Scapular winging is 
prominent, even in infants. Flattening or even concavity of the deltoid contour is seen, and the 
biceps and triceps brachii muscles are wasted and weak. Eventually, proximal muscles get 
involved and undergo atrophy, and Gowers sign & Trendelenburg gait appear. Lumbar 
lordosis, foot drop, and kyphoscoliosis are common complications. Treatment includes orthopedic measures for scoliosis and foot drop, surgical intervention for 
scapular deformity. Physiotherapy has no value. Other options: Long thoracic nerve palsy: No history of trauma or surgery rules out this diagnosis. Klippel-Feil syndrome: Classic triad of Klippel–Feil syndrome (congenital musculoskeletal 
condition) • low posterior hairline • short neck • decreased cervical range of motion Myotonic dystrophy patients have a characteristic V-shaped upper lip, a history of myotonia, and 
progressive weakness. 700 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, 
there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are 
normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical picture showing pain in the calves occuring within a week of an upper respiratory 
tract infection (URI), with elevated creatine kinase levels suggests the diagnosis of viral myositis. 
The specific history of URI suggests influenza myositis. Infectious myositis has a male predominance and is typically seen in young adults. Childhood 
form presents with fever, malaise, and rhinorrhea and is usually followed by severe pain, 
especially in the calves. The muscle pain is usually worse with movement and the symptoms last 
for about a week. In children, toe walking and wide-based gait may be seen because of the 
involvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles. Other viral causes of myositis include HIV-1 (one of the most common causes of myositis), group 
B coxsackievirus (epidemic myalgia), HTLV-1 (Human T-lymphotropic virus), and 
cytomegalovirus (CMV). Lab features of influenza myositis include elevated CK which may be as high as 500 times normal 
the value. Urine myoglobin is usually positive. Detection of the virus with PCR testing of 
nasopharyngeal specimens can be carried out but is not of much clinical significance. The 
histopathological examination would reveal muscle fiber necrosis without much inflammatory 
change. Treatment includes bed rest, IV fluids, and symptomatic management with analgesics and 
antipyretics. Amantadine and other antiviral agents may be considered in adults. Complications 
include myocarditis and respiratory dysfunction. Rhabdomyolysis is an uncommon complication.

questions.question:
Question 7: Rekha brought her 5-day-old infant to the clinic because of feeding difficulties. She says he 
does not latch properly. Her antenatal history is significant for polyhydramnios and 
decreased fetal movements. On examination, hypotonia and hyporeflexia are noted in the 
baby. which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, only Spinal muscular atrophy presents in infancy. The rest present in 
late childhood. Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is a degenerative disease of motor neurons, that is inherited in 
an autosomal recessive manner. It usually starts in infancy with hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and thin 
muscle mass (atrophy). Polyhydramnios may be present prenatally due to weakness in 
swallowing. Diagnosis is done by genetic testing for SMN gene mutation. Muscle biopsy is done for cases with 
negative genetic testing and strong clinical suspicion. The muscle biopsy in infancy shows a 
characteristic pattern of perinatal denervation that is unlike that of a mature muscle. Groups of 
giant type I fibers are mixed with fascicles of severely atrophic fibers. Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Recent updates: • Nusinersen is an antisense oligonucleotide approved by the FDA for treating SMA. It is 
administered intrathecally. • Risdiplam (first oral drug) has been approved by FDA to treat infants >2 months of age with 
SMA. It is an oral splicing modifier that corrects the splicing defect of SMN2, which leads to 701 
Sold by @itachibot increased levels of full-length SMN protein.

questions.question:
Question 8: Pinky, a high school girl, has difficulty in combing her hair and climbing up stairs since 6 
months. On examination, Gower sign is positive and maculopapular rash present over MCP 
joints. What is the next appropriate investigation to be done? 694 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
A maculopapular rash over the metacarpophalangeal joints is indicative of Gottron papules in a 
child with proximal muscle weakness is suggestive of juvenile dermatomyositis. As it is an 
inflammatory myopathy, the next investigation is serum creatine kinase. Though the gold standard investigation is a muscle biopsy, it is indicated only when the diagnosis 
is in doubt or when grading of the disease severity is required. Nerve conduction studies are 
usually normal unless associated with severe muscle necrosis and atrophy. Electromyography 
would show the characteristic signs of myopathy and muscle fiber necrosis but is preferably 
performed in a specialized center.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 1-day-old girl is being evaluated for decreased muscle tone. On examination, thin cheeks, 
high arched palate, inverted V-shaped upper lip, and a narrow head are observed. Facial 
muscle wasting is prominent. She has a club foot deformity. Her mother has a history of 
delayed relaxation of hand muscles after opening doors. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The patient's clinical features along with the history of myotonia in the mother are suggestive of 
Myotonic dystrophy. Facial weakness, inverted V-shaped upper lip, and loss of muscle mass in the 
temporal fossae are characteristic of myotonic muscular dystrophy. A severe congenital form of myotonic dystrophy appears in infants born to mothers with 
symptomatic myotonic dystrophy. It is inherited as an autosomal-dominant trait. Clinical features 
include: • Skeletal deformities (clubfoot deformities alone or congenital contractures involving many joints 
and can even include the cervical spine). • Generalized hypotonia and weakness at birth • Facial wasting and weakness • Inverted V-shaped upper lip • Loss of muscle mass in the temporal fossa Infants can require gavage feeding or ventilator support for respiratory muscle weakness or 
apnea. Other Options: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy with 
hypotonia but has no facial features that are present in this child. In Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the baby appears normal at birth and the facial features present 
in this child are not seen. Emery–Dreifuss muscular dystrophy presents with predominant involvement of scapular and 
humeral muscles. The given scenario makes this diagnosis less likely. 702 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A small baby who was being evaluated for multiple bone fractures with minor trauma is 
found to have brittle bone disease. Which of the following is false regarding this disease?

options.a: It is caused by defects in type 2 collagen.
options.c: Blue sclerae and deafness may be associated.
options.d: Biphosphonates are useful in the treatment.

questions.explanation:
Brittle bone disease is another name for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). It is due to defects in type 1 
collagen, not type 2 collagen. There are 12 types of OI, with type 1 being the most common. Triad of fragile bones, blue sclera, 
and deafness is known as van der Hoeve syndrome. Treatment includes bisphosphonate therapy 
and orthopedic rehabilitation.

questions.question:
Question 11: All of the following are radiological signs of scurvy except  
.
questions.explanation:
White line of Frankel, ground-glass appearance, and zone of rarefaction are the radiological signs 
seen in scurvy. Radiological signs in scurvy includes: • White line of Frankel: calcified cartilage at metaphyses • Trummerfeld zone: lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line • Pelkan spur: lateral prolongation of the white line, which is present at the cortical ends • Wimberger ring sign: circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of 
ossification

questions.question:
Question 12: A 6-month-old infant presents with anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. X-ray imaging done as 
a part of the skeletal survey showed the following image. What is the diagnosis?

options.c: A 18-year-old with RF negative Polyarthritis first diagnosed 3 years back

questions.explanation:
Anemia and hepatosplenomegaly in an infant with the X-ray image showing dense bones, and 
bone within the bone appearance is suggestive of osteopetrosis. Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers–Schönberg disease It is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 in osteoclasts. 703 
Sold by @itachibot Clinical features include macrocephaly, developmental delay, anemia (reduced bone marrow 
cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis). Low serum 
calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D 
levels are observed. Radiological features include diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of 
metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies 
can be seen (image). Treatment is symptomatic. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be 
done in severe cases. Achondroplasia usually presents with pulmonary symptoms like dyspnea, obstructive sleep apnea, 
and recurrent infections. In both scurvy and osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), the child cries on touching. On radiography, 
certain typical features are seen in scurvy, while multiple fractures are seen in OI. 704 
Sold by @itachibot Paediatric Rheumatology
